column1: Dubrajpur is a city and a municipality in Suri Sadar subdivision of Birbhum district in the Indian state of West Bengal.
Dubrajpur is located at 23.8°N 87.38°E﻿ / 23.8; 87.38. It has an average elevation of 77 metres (252 feet).
The place has good connectivity with the rest of the state as well as other states such as  Jharkhand
column3: Assam. NH 60 passes right through the place which connects the place with North Bengal
column4: Bankura & Paschim Bardhaman districts. SH 14 connects the place with Panagarh in Paschim Bardhaman and Moregram in Murshidabad district. The Dubrajpur Railway Station under Asansol division of Eastern Railways provides connectivity with Kolkata
column10: Malda and many other major stations.

column1: Near Dubrajpur town there is a hill named Mama Bhagne. A large number of large sized rocks are found in the area. Two remarkable pieces of these rocks were known as Mama and Bhagne (maternal uncle and nephew). Subsequently
column2: the entire area came to be known as Mama Bhagne. Mama Bhagne pahar (hill) is now a picnic and tourist spot.

column3: 752. Males constitute 52% of the population and females 48%. Dubrajpur has an average literacy rate of 56%
column4: lower than the national average of 59.5%: male literacy is 65% and
column6: 14% of the population is under 6 years of age.

column1: It is believed that when Rama decided to attack Ravana
column2: he found it necessary to throw a bridge across the straits for the conveyance of his troops
column3: he drove in his aerial chariot to the Himalayas
column4: picked up what stones he needed and drove back. As he was passing Dubrajpur his horses took fright and tilted up the chariot and so some stones fell out. These are the stones at Mama Bhagne.There is another legend to the effect that they were collected by Viswakarma
column6: to erect in one night a second Kasi. When he collected the rocks and was about to commence work
